title-group.article-title: Low-frequency noise radiation from traffic-induced vibration of steel double-box girder bridge

abstract.p: Low-frequency noise radiated from bridge vibrations has been reported as an environmental noise problem in many countries. In order to investigate the mechanism of low-frequency noise radiated from bridge vibration, a steel bridge with a double-box is adopted for study. Modal parameters of the bridge, including natural frequency, damping ratio and mode shape, are identified from field tests by a combination of Eigensystem Realization Algorithm and Fast Fourier Transformation. Then the grillage model of the bridge is established and physics parameters of the model are updated by genetic algorithm according to identified natural frequencies. The dynamic response of the bridge by the action of a moving vehicle is calculated and assumed as the sound source of low-frequency noise. Then low-frequency noise due to bridge vibration is estimated according to sound wave propagation theories. The validity of the numerical method is verified through comparison with experimental results. Furthermore, noise reduction methods are proposed and corresponding effects are discussed. Results show that numerical simulation is feasible in assessing low-frequency noise due to traffic induced vibration of a bridge, which offers a possible way for environmental assessment as well as being a good reference for noise reduction design of bridges. The deck plate of the bridge is the primary source of low-frequency noise. Hence, increasing the stiffness of a deck plate is effective for noise control. Improving the road roughness can also reduce low-frequency noise.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Over the last two decades, low-frequency noise has become an environmental pollution problem throughout the world (Mirowska, 1998, 2001; Persson and Rylander, 1988; Rylander, 2004). A lot of research, such as that by Kjellberg et al. (1996), Lundquist et al. (2000), Persson et al. (1997, 2001) and Waye et al. (2003) has indicated that low-frequency noise has negative effects on people's lives, including sleepiness, work, study etc. People with long term exposure to low-frequency noise have a high risk of symptoms such as repeated headache, chest tightness, hypertension, insomnia etc.

There are many sources generating low-frequency noise, such as pumps, diesel engines, aircrafts, shipping vehicles, air turbulence, wind, fans, etc. Bridge vibration is also a kind of low-frequency noise source, which has been reported as one of the environmental problems to the residents living close to bridges. Especially for some steel bridges, because of their light weight and low stiffness, low-frequency noise problems are more likely to happen to the residents nearby.

A lot of research has been conducted analytically and experimentally to investigate the low-frequency noise radiation problem of bridges. Chanpheng et al. (2004) used the concept of radiation modes to identify the characteristics of low-frequency noise radiated from bridge vibration and to design the active controller of low-frequency noise radiation. Lee et al. (2005) used flat plate element to simulate the fluid-structure interactions in an acoustic finite element model of a bridge in order to discuss the main factors that affected the traffic-induced vibration noise of the bridge. Kawatani et al. (2008) applied a boundary element method (BEM) to calculate the traffic-induced low-frequency noise radiated from a continuous steel box girder bridge. The low frequency sound pressure level was estimated based on the velocity response of the bridge, where the velocity response was obtained from a three dimensional bridge-vehicle coupling vibration analysis. Xie et al. (2008) investigated the characteristics of low-frequency noise of a simply supported steel box-girder bridge subjected to moving vehicles by using a grillage model. Ding et al. (2009) analyzed the low-frequency noise of a bridge using a shell finite element model to account for the effects of higher-order modes. Xia et al. (2009) reviewed the theoretical method for analysis of structure-borne noise, the features of noises induced by different types of elevated bridges and their influence on the environment. Murai (1999) conducted a field measurement study on the distribution of low-frequency noise around viaducts. Ngai and Ng (2002) gave a relationship between structure-borne noise and structural vibration based on the measurement results of a concrete box girder rail bridge. Gao et al. (2010) carried out an experimental and analytical study of Beijing Metro Line 5 to obtain the characteristics of the structural vibration noise and wheel-rail noise near elevated structures. Moreover, measures of reducing low-frequency noise generated by structural vibration have been developed in some studies. Oude and Hermanus (2003) used piezoelectric patches as control actuators to develop an active control method for reducing the structural-vibration-borne low-frequency noise, and an efficient analysis was performed as a tool for estimating active control systems. Wang et al. (2007) discussed the noise reduction method of a steel railway bridge based on experimental results and analytical models. The above research helped to understand the radiation mechanism of low-frequency noise and laid the foundations for developing effective noise reduction methods for structures.

This paper investigates the low-frequency noise radiated from traffic-induced vibration of a steel double box girder bridge by means of field test and numerical analysis. A field test is performed to obtain the dynamic characteristics of the bridge and the low-frequency noise around the bridge. In numerical analysis, a grillage model of the bridge was developed and physical properties were updated through a genetic algorithm (GA) to fit the modal parameters identified from the field test. From vehicle–bridge coupling vibration analysis the dynamic responses of the bridge were calculated as a sound source. Then low-frequency noise radiated from bridge vibration was estimated based on sound propagation theory. Furthermore, based on the numerical analysis the radiation property of low-frequency noise is obtained, and noise reduction methods are proposed with the corresponding effectiveness assessed through comparative analysis.

sec.title: 2.1. Bridge description and field test
sec.p:
A three-span continuous steel double box girder bridge is adopted for study. The span arrangement is 54.6 m + 73.0 m + 54.6 m. The general layout and cross-section of the bridge are shown in Figure 1. It is seen from the figure that the bridge superstructure is constituted of two separate steel box girders and an orthotropic steel deck-plate lying under the bottom of the two box girders. In addition, a cantilever sidewalk is at each side of the midspan as denoted in Figure 1. Two supports are located under each girder to resist the torsional displacement. Figure 1.
Sketch of bridge.

A field test is conducted to investigate the dynamic and low-frequency noise radiation characteristics of the bridge. The test has two parts: the dynamic vibration test, which records the acceleration responses of bridge girders and deck plate, and the low-frequency noise test for measuring the low-frequency sound pressure level (SPL) from the bridge vibration.

In the vibration test, acceleration sensors, data recorder and FFT analyzer are used to record the dynamic acceleration response of girders and the deck plate. The arrangement of acceleration sensors is shown in Figure 2. Eight accelerator sensors (B1∼B8 in Figure 2(a)) are installed on the bottom flanges of two box girders to measure the vertical vibration of girders. Nine accelerator sensors (D1∼D9 in Figure 2(b)) are fixed at the middle of the side span to measure the local vibration of the deck plate. The test was performed under two load conditions separately: ambient excitation (traffic free) and a certain traffic load. The sampling frequency was 100 Hz, a value that is much higher than necessary in the test of the bridge. Figure 2.
Arrangement of accelerator and sound pressure sensors.

In the low-frequency noise test, the low-frequency SPL was measured by the sound sensors (frequency coverage 1–1 kHz, SPL coverage 53–147 dB). Three sound sensors are used in the test, where two (L2-L3 in Figure 2(a)) are located near the abutment and one (L1 in Figure 2(a)) at the midspan. Considering the influence of sound wave reflection from the abutment and buildings, only the sensor at midspan (L1) is adopted to extract the characteristics of low-frequency noise. The sensor L1 is 1.2 m above the ground and 4.5 m beneath the bottom of the bridge (see Figure 2(a)). The excitation condition is the same with the vibration test, while the ambient condition is applied to indicate that other noise besides the vehicle-induced vibration noise is negligible during the test. For traffic load conditions, in order to obtain the frequency components of low-frequency noise when heavy vehicles move through, 1/3 octave analysis is performed on the time series of SPL. The analysis is conducted through 1/3 octave analyzer and the result is recorded by data recorder. Note that only the period with thecorresponding SPL falls between peak value and (peak-5) value is used for analysis. Through 1/3 octave analysis the amplitude of SPL corresponding to each frequency band is obtained. The frequency coverage is 1–80 Hz in analysis, which has included the frequency concerned.

sec.title: 2.2. Modal parameter identification
sec.p:
From Fast Fourier Transformation (FFT) analysis the acceleration response spectra of girder and deck plate under ambient excitation (traffic free) are depicted in Figure 3. Figure 3(a) shows the vibration of box girders. It is seen that the vibration of the box girder is dominated by frequencies at 1.20 Hz, 1.95 Hz, 2.30 Hz, 3.60 Hz and 3.80 Hz. Figure 3(b) shows the vibration of the deck plate, it contains local vibration with predominant frequencies at 9.85 Hz and 13.9 Hz, except for the same predominant frequencies as in box girder. Figure 3.
Acceleration response spectra of the bridge due to micro-tremor.

In order to obtain the natural frequency, mode shape and damping ratio of the bridge, the ERA method (Juang and Pappa, 1985) is adopted to analyze the acceleration responses of the bridge. The data used in ERA is a free decaying response after the vehicle passes through the bridge. To exclude the causal factors in experiment, measurements are performed several times to form enough sample sets. Figure 4 gives an example of the free decaying responses of the box girder and the deck plate. Figure 4.
Example of free decaying acceleration response.

The above procedure is firstly applied to the vibration signal of a box girder. The modal parameters obtained are summarized in Table 1. In the table, B1-B8 corresponds to the locations of acceleration meters on the box girder, and the dotted line represents the original shape of the structure. The dominant modes of the bridge are: 1) The first order symmetric vertical bending: f = 1.199 Hz; 2) The first order asymmetric vertical bending: f = 1.946 Hz; 3) The second order symmetric vertical bending: f = 5.72 Hz; 4) The torsion modes: f = 3.603 Hz and f = 3.763 Hz; 5) The bending-torsion coupling mode: f = 2.299 Hz. The damping ratio of the bridge is around 0.5%, which is a typical value for steel bridges. Table 1.
Natural frequency, modal damping ratio and mode shape of box girder

The same procedure is then applied to the vibration signal of the deck plate. As discussed before, local vibration with the frequency range of 10–15 Hz is remarkable in the vibration of the deck plate. However, because the frequency distribution of Figure 3(b) is dense in this frequency range, direct comparison between the frequencies from ERA and FFT in this range is difficult. As an alternative, frequencies stable in most datasets are taken as predominant frequencies of deck plate in local vibration. However, this may lead to lower accuracy in the identification of deck plate parameters.

Vibration of the deck plate can be classified into two groups: global vibration and local vibration. The global vibration with the frequency below 9 Hz is observed both at the vibration of the box girder and the deck plate and the corresponding modal parameters are shown in Table 1, while the local vibration with the frequency range of 10∼15 Hz only exists at the vibration of the deck plate and the obtained modal parameters are shown in Table 2. The local vibration of the deck plate is independent of the vibration of the box girder. The largest damping ratio is 1.75% for the frequency of 15.029 Hz, while most of modal damping ratios are around 0.5%. Table 2.
Natural frequency, modal damping ratio and mode shape of the deck plate

sec.title: 2.3. Analytical model of the bridge and model updating
sec.p:
In order to consider the effect of local vibration of the deck plate, a grillage model is applied for analysis. The plan view and cross-sectional view of the grillage model are shown in Figure 5. In this figure the stiffness of a longitudinal beam considers contributions from longitudinal ribs and the deck plate, while the stiffness of a transverse beam comes from that of cross ribs and the deck plate. The stiffness of the sidewalk in the midspan is neglected in the model, while the corresponding self weight is included by adding its mass to adjacent box girder element. The boundary conditions are considered according to the arrangement of supports. Figure 5.
Grillage model of the bridge.

The natural frequencies of the bridge from the grillage model are shown in Table 3, together with the frequencies identified from Section 2.2. Some differences exist between the analytical and experimental results, which are caused by inaccuracy in material properties, geometry dimensions and boundary conditions. To minimize these differences, model updating is carried out through genetic algorithm (Goldberg, 1989; Mitchell, 1998). GA is a stochastic global search technique for optimization problems. Based on the mechanics of natural evolution, it uses techniques such as inheritance, mutation, selection, and crossover to let individuals evolve toward better ones. The algorithms usually have the following steps: 1) Randomly generate an initial population; 2) Calculate the fitness for each individual in the current population; 3) Define selection probabilities for each individual; 4) Generate offspring by probabilistically selecting individuals from the previous generation via genetic operators; 5) Repeat step 2) until the solution is satisfactory. Table 3.
Comparison of natural frequency between experiment and grillage model
Mode Experimental (Hz) Original grillage model Updated grillage model
Frequency (Hz) Relative error (%) Frequency (Hz) Relative error (%)
Mode-1 1.20 1.20 0.0 1.20 0.0
Mode-2 1.95 2.13 9.3 2.10 7.7
Mode-3 2.30 2.20 4.5 2.23 1.3
Mode-4 3.60 3.84 6.7 3.76 4.4

In the model updating part of this paper, natural frequencies of the first four modal shapes are adopted as objective function, and the stiffness and mass of the grillage model are debugged until they achieve sufficient fitness, while the boundary conditions remain unchanged. In order to let the obtained physical properties fall within an acceptable and realistic range, the maximum variation range of stiffness and mass is 7% of the initial value in this model updating procedure. In addition, the modes of local vibration have not been used in the updating process, because the modes of local vibration are so complicated that direct comparison of local vibration is unfeasible. The natural frequencies from the experiment, the original model and the updated model are given in Table 3. It can be seen that the difference of every mode between the experiment and athe analytical model decreases, indicating that the precision of the model is improved after model updating. The updated model will be used in the following analysis.

sec.title: 2.4. The vehicle–bridge coupling vibration system
sec.p: The vehicle–-bridge coupling vibration system is composed of bridge model, vehicle model and vehicle–bridge interaction system. The bridge model has been introduced in Section 2.3. It should be noted that the Rayleigh damping is employed to describe the damping of the bridge, where the coefficients of mass and stiffness determined from the identified damping ratio as depicted in Table 1 and Table 2 are equal to 0.2 and 0.0002 respectively.

The vehicle model used in this paper is shown in Figure 6. Six degrees-of-freedom (d.f.) are used to describe its movement. The vehicle parameters are summarized in Table 4, with the notations defined in Figure 6. In Table 4, the notation of J, m, k, c and λ denote the moment of inertia, the mass, the spring stiffness, the damping coefficient and the length, respectively. The vehicle speed is set to be 40 km/h, which is close to the speed of vehicle in field test. Figure 6.

For the vehicle–bridge interaction system, considering the fine surface condition of the bridge, the surface roughness of the bridge is idealized to a stationary Gaussian random process, which is described by a good power spectral density (PSD) function. The simulated vertical profile of the bridge is presented in Figure 7, in which r represents surface roughness and x is the longitudinal distance to the beginning of the bridge. Figure 7.
Vertical profile of the bridge surface.

The acceleration responses from experiment and analysis are compared in Figure 8. The analytical response of the bridge using the previously described system is shown in Figure 8(a). Figure 8(b) demonstrates the experimental response of the bridge at the center of the midspan and side span when a vehicle weighing roughly 200 kN passes over the bridge at a speed of around 40 km/h. The similarity in these two figures verifies the validity of the vehicle–bridge coupling analysis for simulating the response of the bridge vibration under traffic load. Figure 8.
Acceleration response of numerical model and field test.

sec.title: 3. Characteristic of low-frequency noise radiation from bridge vibration
sec.p: In this section the dynamic response of the bridge obtained from vehicle–bridge coupling vibration analysis is taken as noise source. Then the low-frequency noise radiated from the bridge vibration is calculated based on dynamic response through the theory of sound propagation.

sec.title: 3.1. Sound pressure level from bridge vibration
sec.p:
According to the theory of sound propagation, the sound pressure due to bridge vibration can be obtained by summation of every small point source on the bridge surface (see Figure 9). Assuming that the velocity of the air in contact with the bridge surface is identical to thevelocity of the bridge surface, the sound pressure P(X, t, f) of point X at time t corresponding to vibration frequency f can be written as (Cremer et al., 2005): (1) where, ρa and ca are air density and the speed of sound propagation in air, taken as 1.205 kg/m3 and 343.0 m/s respectively, k = ω/ca the wavenumber, ω the circular frequency (rad/s), f the vibration frequency of source (Hz), ri the distance between point X and the point source i, ui the vertical velocity of the point source i in the bridge surface, ΔAi the surface area of the point source i, and n is the total number of the point sources. Figure 9.
Calculation of sound pressure by summation of the point sources.

The SPL can be calculated by its definition once the sound pressure is obtained from equation (1). To verify the calculation method, the contrast between experimental and analytical SPL at point L1 (see Figure 2(a)) is depicted in Figure 10. The analytical result is calculated under the condition introduced in Section 2.4. The experimental results are obtained under the traffic load conditions as described previously. The experiment was repeated several times to check the repeatability. The repeating experimental SPL are represented by multiple sets of thin lines in Figure 10, while the analytical SPL is represented by the dark red line. In Figure 10 the vertical and horizontal axes denote the SPL in dB and 1/3 octave band frequency, respectively. Figure 10.
Analytical and experimental sound pressure level at point L1.

As shown in Figure 10, experimental and analytical SPL accord quite well with each other, especially at the frequency below 5 Hz. The difference at the frequency range of 5–16 Hz appears larger. This is possibly because the grillage model is only updated according to the global modes of the bridge, of which the natural frequencies are all below 5 Hz. The good agreement between experimental and analytical results in Figure 10 demonstrated that it is feasible to calculate SPL using the applied method, as long as the bridge model can represent the vibration characteristics of the real bridge.

It is also observed in Figure 10 that there are three peaks in the SPL spectrum, and the corresponding 1/3-octave band center frequencies are 1.25 Hz, 2.5 Hz and 8–16 Hz respectively. The predominant frequencies 1.25 Hz and 2.5 Hz are mainly caused by the vibration of the first three modes of the bridge, which are 1.2 Hz, 2.1 Hz and 2.3 Hz in Table 2, respectively. The SPL in the frequency range of 8–16 Hz is more remarkable than that of the first two predominant frequencies. Back to Figure 3, it is found that the vibration with the frequency range of 8–16 Hz only exists in the local vibration of deck plate, i.e. the SPL at the third peak (8–16 Hz) is mainly generated from the local vibration of deck plate. Thus, it is concluded that the most important source of low-frequency noise radiated from bridge vibration is the local vibration of the deck plate.

sec.title: 3.2. Sound power from bridge vibration
sec.p: Sound power W is a measure of sonic energy transferred by the sound source in unit time. It is measured in watts or the product of sound intensity I and area A. It is neither space dependent nor distance dependent, but belongs strictly to the sound source (Wikipedia). The vibration response of the bridge under a 200 kN moving vehicle with a speed of 40 km/h is adopted in the calculation of sound power. The variation of sound power against the position of the vehicle is shown in Figure 11, with the vertical axis representing the sound power of the bridge and the horizontal axis representing the location of the vehicle. When the vehicle moves around the midpoint of each span, the sound power tends to be larger and dominated by lower frequency components, compared with the vehicle near the abutment or pier. This is because, when the vehicle is at the middle of each span, the amplitude of the bridge vibration is larger and vibration components with low frequencies become more predominant. Figure 11.
The sound power of bridge under moving vehicle.

Considering that the sound power is dependent on the velocity of the structure and that the vibration around the midpoint of each span is the main source generating the low-frequency noise, the velocities at the center of each span along the bridge centerline are analyzed to get insight into the low-frequency noise radiated from the bridge. On the other hand, in order to investigate the effect of vehicle location on the frequency component of the vibration around the midpoint of each span, wavelet transformation is performed on the velocity response of the concerned point. The velocity responses of the three points and their corresponding wavelet transformations are shown in Figure 12. In the wavelet transformation, Morlet wavelet (Ruzzene et al., 1997; Torrence and Compo, 1998) is adopted. It is observed that the local vibration of the point (vibration in the frequency range of 8–16 Hz) is most prominent only when the vehicle is close to the point. However, the global vibration (with frequency below 5 Hz) is consistently prominent during the whole process. That is, the local vibration of the deck plate only exists in the vicinity of moving vehicles. Figure 12.
Velocity response and wavelet-transformation at center of three spans.

sec.title: 4. Comparative analysis of noise reduction methods
4.1. Noise reduction methods
sec.p:
The effect of different parameters on the low-frequency noise radiated from the bridge is investigated in this section. The parameters considered are: 1) vehicle speed; 2) the roughness of the road surface; 3) the stiffness of the crossbeams; and 4) the stiffness of the box girders. Five different cases are investigated to identify the effect of each parameter, as shown in Table 5. In the table, Case 1 serves as the baseline, which has been discussed in Section 3.2. The other four cases are obtained by changing one of the four parameters (multiplied by the amplification factor shown in Table 5) of Case 1. For example the crossbeam stiffness of Case 4 is twice that of Case 1 while keeping the other factors unchanged. Table 5.

sec.title: 4.2. Comparative analysis of noise reduction methods
sec.p:
The effectiveness of noise reduction methods is assessed by comparing the SPL and sound power of the five cases. The SPL at point L1 for all cases is shown in Figure 13. From Figure 13, it is concluded that: 1) vehicle speed only has effect on the noise below 5 Hz, and the SPL value increases with the increase of vehicle speed in this frequency range; 2) road surface roughness has an effect on the noise in all frequency components, more roughness leads to larger SPL at whole frequency range; 3) the effect of crossbeam stiffness is most obvious in the frequency range of 10∼20 Hz, which is the range of local vibration of the deck plate; 4) increasing the stiffness of box girders only reduces the SPL below 3 Hz, which is the frequency range of the global vibration of the bridge. Because the low-frequency noise in the frequency range of 10–20 Hz is most remarkable from the field test, as shown in Figure 10, increasing the stiffness of crossbeams is the most effective measure in reducing low-frequency noise. Moreover, improving the road surface roughness is also useful in low-frequency noise control. Figure 13.
Sound pressures from five cases at sensor L1.

Figure 14 shows the variation of sound power against vehicle position x for the cases with the vehicle speed at 40 km/h. It is shown that road surface roughness has a significant effect on the sound power. The sound power rises remarkably with an increase in road surface roughness, and the stiffness of the box girder also influences the sound power. Figure 14.
Sound power of the bridge under Cases 1, 3, 4 and 5.

From the above discussion, it can be seen that pavement roughness has a great effect on the low-frequency noise radiated from bridge vibration. To further investigate the effect of pavement roughness, the SPL spectra under four different roughness conditions are analyzed and presented in Figure 15. The legend in the figure represents the amplification factor of road surface roughness shown in Figure 7. Figure 15 shows that the SPL can be reduced by more than 10 dB if the pavement roughness is decreased from two times the base condition to one half. This demonstrates the importance of bridge structures to keep good surface conditions. Figure 15.
Sound pressure level under different road surface roughness.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p:
In this paper, a steel continuous bridge with two separate box girders is employed to investigate the mechanism of low-frequency noise radiated from traffic-induced vibration of a bridge. A grillage model of the bridge is firstly established and then updated using a genetic algorithm to fit the modal parameters from a field test. Based on the dynamic response of the bridge, sound pressure level and sound power are calculated according to sound propagation theories. Moreover, different noise reduction methods are proposed and corresponding effects are compared. In summary, the following conclusions are drawn:
The numerical method, including the vehicle–bridge coupling vibration analysis and point source superposition method, is feasible in the calculation of low-frequency noise radiated from bridge structures;
The local vibration of the deck plate in the frequency range of 10–20 Hz is the primary source of low-frequency noise for this type of bridge structure. Thus increasing the stiffness of crossbeams appears an effective way of solving the low-frequency noise problem. On the other hand, improving the surface condition is considered as an alternative noise reduction method due to its significant effect on reducing the noise in overall frequency range.
Limiting the vehicle speed and increasing the box girder stiffness are not very effective in terms of noise reduction, though they can help reduce noise with a frequency below 5 Hz.
